Further, phenotypic diversity of invasive species can be affected by the number of introduction events to the new region, which increases the genetic novelties
27â€“ 29 . For example, numerous introductions of Phalaris arundinaceae L. to the invasive range in North America have been found to increase phenotypic and genetic diversity. Those events stimulated the rapid evolution and phenotypic plasticity, facilitating range expansion
30 . Likewise, the multiple introductions of S. madagascariensis in Brazil are a gene source that might ensure a higher variability in dispersal traits of the invasive populations
31 .
